Alexandros Daglis is an Assistant Professor of Computer Science at Georgia Tech with an adjunct appointment at the School of Electrical and Computer Engineering.

Yunan Luo is an assistant professor in the School of Computational Science and Engineering (CSE), Georgia Institute of Technology.

**Research Areas:** Her research focuses on computational biology and machine learning, with interests including machine learning, geometric deep learning, generative models, network and system biology, functional genomics, cancer genomics, drug repositioning and discovery, and AI-guided protein engineering. Other areas of interest are deep learning, transfer learning, sequence and graph representation learning, and AI-guided biological design and discovery.

**Notable Publications:** Key publications include the MODIFY paper published in Nature Communications, a KDBNet paper published in Nature Machine Intelligence, and an enzyme function prediction paper published in Science. Another notable publication is "Machine learning-guided co-optimization of fitness and diversity facilitates combinatorial library design in enzyme engineering" in Nature Communications.

**Current Projects:** Luo's current projects include receiving an Azure grant from Microsoft's Accelerating Foundation Models Research Initiative, an NIH MIRA award, and a Seed Grant Award from the NSF AI Institute MMLI. She also received an Amazon Research Award in 2022 for calibrated and interpretable geometric deep learning for robust drug screening.

**Teaching Interests:** She teaches courses such as CSE7850/CX4803, Machine Learning for Computational Biology, and CSE8803 MLG, Machine Learning with Graphs.

**Academic Background:** Yunan Luo received her PhD in 2021 from the Department of Computer Science at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, and her bachelor's degree in Computer Science from Yao Class at Tsinghua University in 2016.

Markov Chain Monte Carlo, Statistical Physics, Combinatorial Algorithms, Approximate Counting, Sampling Algorithms, Gibbs Distributions, Spin Systems, Graph Algorithms, Computational Complexity, Discrete Probability

Zongchen Chen is an Assistant Professor in the School of Computer Science at Georgia Tech.

**Research Areas:** Randomized algorithms, discrete probability, machine learning, Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods, approximate counting and sampling.

**Notable Publications:** Some of his publications include "Hardcore Model on Random Regular Graphs beyond Uniqueness", "Rapid Mixing at the Uniqueness Threshold", and "Counting random k-SAT near the satisfiability threshold".

**Current Projects:** His current research focuses on Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods, approximate counting and sampling, and learning and testing of high-dimensional distributions.

**Teaching Interests:** He teaches courses such as CS 3510 Design and Analysis of Algorithms, CS 8803 Counting and Sampling, and CSE 632 Analysis of Algorithms II: Randomized Algorithms.

**Academic Background:** He received his PhD degree in Algorithms, Combinatorics and Optimization (ACO) from the School of Computer Science at Georgia Tech in 2021. He also holds a BS degree in Mathematics & Applied Mathematics from Zhiyuan College at Shanghai Jiao Tong University in 2016.
Machine Learning, Computer Vision, Artificial Intelligence, Robotics, Deep Learning, Transfer Learning, Continual Learning, Multi-Agent Systems, Domain Adaptation, Object Detection

Zsolt Kira is an Associate Professor in the School of Interactive Computing at Georgia Tech.

Zsolt Kira is an Associate Professor in the School of Interactive Computing at Georgia Tech.

**Research Areas:** His research focuses on the intersection of learning methods for sensor processing and robotics, developing novel machine learning algorithms, and formulations for perception problems. He is particularly interested in moving beyond supervised learning, including areas like un/semi/self-supervised and continual/lifelong learning, as well as distributed perception, such as multi-modal fusion.

**Notable Publications:** Recent publications include works on Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models, robust VLM finetuning, and diffusion-based representations for robotics. Specific papers include those presented at NeurIPS on action tokenization and robust finetuning of Foundation Models.

**Current Projects:** Kira leads the RobotIcs Perception and Learning (RIPL) lab at Georgia Tech. He also serves as an Associate Director of ML@GT, the machine learning center at Georgia Tech.

**Teaching Interests:** He teaches courses such as Machine Learning and Deep Learning.

**Academic Background:** He received his Ph.D. in 2010 with Professor Ron Arkin as his advisor. Before joining Georgia Tech, he was a Branch Chief at the Georgia Tech Research Institute (GTRI) and a Research Scientist at SRI International Sarnoff in Princeton.

Algorithms and Data Structures, Graph Algorithms, String Algorithms, Pattern Matching, Dynamic Algorithms, Parallel Algorithms, Computational Complexity, Combinatorial Algorithms, Computational Geometry, Cryptography

Zvi Galil is the Frederick G. Storey Chair in Computing and Executive Advisor to Online Programs at the Georgia Institute of Technology.

**Research Areas:** His research areas include the design and analysis of algorithms, complexity, cryptography, and experimental design. He is also credited with coining the terms stringology and sparsification.

**Notable Publications:** He has written over 200 scientific papers and edited 5 books, with one notable paper being "Explicit Constructions of Linear-Sized Superconcentrators," co-authored with Ofer Gabber.

**Current Projects:** Galil led the faculty in creating Georgia Tech's Online Master of Science in Computer Science (OMSCS) program, which has grown to be the largest master's degree program in the US.

**Teaching Interests:** He teaches courses such as CS 4510 - Automata and Complexity and CS 8903 - Special Problems.

**Academic Background:** Galil earned BS and MS degrees in Applied Mathematics from Tel Aviv University, both summa cum laude. He then obtained a PhD in Computer Science from Cornell University. He also holds an honorary Doctor of Mathematics from the University of Waterloo.
Artificial Intelligence, Theoretical Computer Science, Algorithms, Computational Complexity, Graph Theory, Cryptography, Human-Computer Interaction, Machine Learning, Software Engineering, Education

Merrick Furst, Ph. D., is a Distinguished Professor in the College of Computing at Georgia Tech.

**Research Areas:** Algorithms, complexity theory, artificial intelligence (AI), commercialization, and new venture creation.

**Notable Publications:** He co-authored *The Heart of Innovation: A Field Guide for Navigating to Authentic Demand*. Furst also co-invented probabilistic circuit analysis and planning graphs.

**Current Projects:** Dr. Furst directs undergraduate programs and faculty development in the College of Computing and is the Director of the Center for Deliberate Innovation at Georgia Tech. He also founded Flashpoint@GT, a startup engineering studio.

**Teaching Interests:** He teaches a variety of courses including Undergraduate Research, Startup Lab, Comp Sci Ventures, Dsgn&Analysis-Algorithms, Automata and Complexity, and VIP Proj Team.

**Academic Background:** Prior to Georgia Tech, he was a professor at UC Berkeley, president of the International Computer Science Institute at Berkeley, and earlier, a professor and associate dean in the School of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University. He received his PhD in Computer Science from Cornell University.
Robotics, Computer Vision, Motion Planning, Visual Servoing, Robot Control, Multi-Robot Systems, Geometric Algorithms, Sensor Fusion, Machine Learning, Automation

Seth Hutchinson is currently Professor and KUKA Chair for Robotics in the School of Interactive Computing at Georgia Tech, and was the Executive Director of the Institute for Robotics and Intelligent Machines (IRIM) from 2019-2024.

**Research Areas:** His research interests include robotics, vision-based control, motion planning, planning under uncertainty, pursuit-evasion, localization and mapping, locomotion, and bio-inspired robotics. Additional research interests include robots operating in dynamic environments, coexisting with other agents, and addressing challenges in automatic control due to the nonlinear, underactuated, redundant, or constrained nature of robots.

**Notable Publications:** He is the coauthor of two books, “Principles of Robot Motion - Theory, Algorithms, and Implementations,” and “Robot Modeling and Control.” He has also published widely with more than 200 publications related to planning, sensing, and control in robotics.

**Current Projects:** Hutchinson collaborates with Prof. Dr. Wolfram Burgard at the University of Technology Nuremberg (UTN) on research initiatives, training programs, and funding arrangements.

**Academic Background:** He holds a Bachelor of Science, Master of Science, and Ph.D. in Electrical Engineering from Purdue University.

Parallel Computing, High Performance Computing, Combinatorial Scientific Computing, Graph Algorithms, Biomedical Informatics, Image Analysis, Scientific Computing, Data Mining, Distributed Computing, Bioinformatics

Ümit V. Çatalyürek is a Professor in the School of Computational Science and Engineering at Georgia Tech.

Ümit V. Çatalyürek is a Professor in the School of Computational Science and Engineering at Georgia Tech.

**Research Areas:** His main research areas include parallel computing, combinatorial scientific computing, and biomedical informatics, with interests in graph and hypergraph partitioning, data decomposition for irregular domains, and parallel graph algorithms.

**Notable Publications:** He has co-authored over 200 peer-reviewed articles. One notable publication is "Hypergraph-partitioning-based decomposition for parallel sparse-matrix vector multiplication." Other works include research on scalable distributed parallel breadth-first search algorithms.

**Current Projects:** Dr. Çatalyürek is the primary investigator of several awards from the Department of Energy, the National Institute of Health, and the National Science Foundation. He has also worked on the GenTen project in collaboration with Sandia National Laboratories.

**Teaching Interests:** He teaches courses such as High Performance Computing, High Perf Parallel Comp, and Comp Sci&Engr Algorithms.

**Academic Background:** He received his Ph.D., M.S., and B.S. degrees in Computer Engineering and Information Science from Bilkent University, Turkey.
